title: Reclaiming Rivers: Communities, Dams, and the Pulse of a Watershed
excerpt: Grassroots groups are rewriting the story of their local rivers — one culvert and one conversation at a time.
author: A. K. Sharma
content:
The river remembers.

For decades, flood control meant concrete. Now, communities are testing a gentler approach: removing obsolete dams, restoring wetlands, and letting water breathe.

“When the salmon returned, so did the stories,” a tribal elder told us.

What changed

  • Dam safety costs are rising.
  • Droughts and flash floods are more frequent.
  • Local coalitions are stronger than ever.

What matters

We asked residents to map places they miss, fear, and love. The resulting atlas didn't just guide projects — it reframed power.

title: Heat at Night: Why Urban Cooling is an Equity Issue
excerpt: Temperatures don't drop evenly after sunset. In some neighborhoods, the heat never lets go.
author: Maya López
content:
Street trees, cool roofs, and renter protections: three levers that can save lives in the dark.

Data we have

City sensors show a 5–8°C difference across districts. That gap maps onto redlining.

Voices

Night-shift workers, caregivers, and unhoused neighbors are living the heat map.

title: Listening to Farms: Interviews from a Drier Future
excerpt: Farmers are engineers of resilience — and reluctant futurists.
author: Samir Patel
content:
From soil moisture hacks to cooperative wells, producers are designing locally-adapted climate tech.

“We plan for the year we might get, not the year we want.”
